name: Educator & Facilitator Fit
description: Evaluates educators/facilitators who can hold relational complexity while building community

targetAudience.description: Educators and facilitators who already think in systems, care about culture/learning/relationships, and can distribute emotional labor
targetAudience.successMetric: Would you move into this community and help build relational infrastructure?

criteria.description: Understands the emotional labor in community building. Sees that relational work matters as much as systems work.

scoreGuide.1-2: Focuses only on systems/structure. Blind to emotional dynamics.
scoreGuide.3-4: Acknowledges relationships matter but doesn't demonstrate depth.
scoreGuide.5-6: Shows awareness that community requires relational work.
scoreGuide.7-8: Articulates specific relational challenges and how to navigate them.
scoreGuide.9-10: Deep understanding of emotional labor, conflict, and relational infrastructure.

criteria.description: Can name doubts AND stay engaged. Holds tension without needing resolution. Courage-as-doubt scores higher than false certainty.

scoreGuide.1-2: Needs certainty. Collapses complexity into simple answers.
scoreGuide.3-4: Acknowledges complexity but seems overwhelmed by it.
scoreGuide.5-6: Can hold some tension. Names doubts but stays curious.
scoreGuide.7-8: 'I'm scared AND I'm still willing' - courage-as-doubt.
scoreGuide.9-10: Thrives in ambiguity. Holds multiple truths without needing to resolve.

criteria.description: Understands that personal freedom and community are linked. Sees how individual choices affect systems and vice versa.

scoreGuide.1-2: Purely individual/transactional. Doesn't connect to systems.
scoreGuide.3-4: Mentions community but doesn't show deep linkage.
scoreGuide.7-8: Sophisticated understanding of interdependence and systems.
scoreGuide.9-10: Systems-level thinking about how living structures, work, and freedom interact.

criteria.description: Has experience holding space for groups, navigating conflict, or teaching. Comfortable with process, not just outcomes.

scoreGuide.1-2: No group facilitation experience. Uncomfortable with process.
scoreGuide.3-4: Some experience but prefers to avoid conflict or messiness.
scoreGuide.5-6: Can facilitate. Has navigated group dynamics before.
scoreGuide.7-8: Skilled facilitator. Comfortable with conflict and emergence.
scoreGuide.9-10: Master facilitator. Sees conflict as generative. Holds groups through difficulty.

criteria.description: Communicates genuinely. Admits uncertainty. 'I don't know' and 'I'm scared' score HIGHER than polished certainty.

scoreGuide.1-3: Performative. Polished. Hides behind expertise or abstraction.
scoreGuide.6-7: Genuine and direct. Admits gaps and uncertainties.
scoreGuide.8-9: Vulnerable. 'I failed at this before and I'm still here.'
scoreGuide.10: Radically honest. No performance. Names fear AND commitment.

criteria.description: Asks about the organizer's thinking and philosophy. Shows interest in mutual exploration, not just being evaluated.

scoreGuide.1-2: Entirely one-directional. No questions about the organizer.
scoreGuide.3-4: Only logistical questions. No philosophical curiosity.
scoreGuide.5-6: At least one genuine question about thinking or philosophy.
scoreGuide.7-8: Multiple thoughtful questions about vision, failures, and learning.
scoreGuide.9-10: Deep reciprocal exploration. 'What have you learned from trying this?'

criteria.description: Comfort with household that includes young children. This is a home, not an office.

scoreGuide.1-3: Discomfort or resentment about children being present.
scoreGuide.8-10: Lights up about it. Has experience. Seeks connection with kids.

logistics.description: Answer fully, bridge to relational dimensions, probe for how they'd navigate the human complexity

relationalProbes.description: Probe for past relational/community experience and what they learned
probes: You mentioned past community work—what broke relationally?
When you imagine day-to-day life here, what's your gut response to conflict?
Where do you think your limits are as a relational leader?
What's the hardest group dynamic you've had to navigate?

courageAsDoubt.description: Someone saying 'I'm scared AND I'm still willing' scores HIGHER on agency, not lower

highAgency: I'm scared and I'm still here
I don't know if I have the energy, but I want to try
I failed at this before and I'm still drawn to it
This terrifies me and that's why I need it
lowAgency: I don't see any problems with this
I never really struggle with conflict

positive: admits uncertainty, fear, or past failures
names specific relational challenges they've faced
asks about what's been hard for the organizer
shows curiosity about the kids, the family, the mess
negative: never asks about what's gone wrong

probes: Tell me about a time you held space for a difficult conversation
How do you handle it when a group gets stuck?
